articles.headline: Madoff Had Accomplices: His Victims
articles.snippet: Only the willfully ignorant could have seen Bernard L. Madoff’s fund as a good investment.
articles.abstract: Only the willfully ignorant could have seen Bernard L. Madoff’s fund as a good investment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Standing in the security line Thursday morning, waiting to get into the federal courthouse in Manhattan, I started chatting with the man behind me. He looked to be in his early 60s, and though he was well dressed, he looked a little haggard. I asked him if he was a victim of Bernard L. Madoff, who would soon be pleading guilty to masterminding the greatest Ponzi scheme in history. He said he was.

articles.headline: Medtronic Links Device for Heart to 13 Deaths
articles.snippet: The new data reflect the first time that Medtronic has updated fatality figures since the device was recalled in October 2007.
articles.abstract: The new data reflect the first time that Medtronic has updated fatality figures since the device was recalled in October 2007.
articles.lead_paragraph: Medtronic said Friday that at least 13 people might have died in connection with a heart device that it recalled in 2007 but was still in widespread use, including four patients whose deaths were related to efforts by doctors to surgically remove the product.

articles.headline: Thoughts on Walking Away From Your Home Loan
articles.snippet: Moral hazard aside, the consequences of giving up on your mortgage may not be as painful as they once were.
articles.abstract: Moral hazard aside, the consequences of giving up on your mortgage may not be as painful as they once were.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’re among the millions of people who will not qualify for the Obama administration’s program to help troubled homeowners, you’re probably wondering what you’re supposed to do now.

articles.headline: U.S. Won’t Label Terror Suspects as ‘Combatants’
articles.snippet: The Obama administration said it would not use “enemy combatant” in reference to Guantánamo Bay detainees, but asserted a power to detain them.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration said it would not use “enemy combatant” in reference to Guantánamo Bay detainees, but asserted a power to detain them.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration said Friday that it would abandon the Bush administration’s term “enemy combatant” as it argues in court for the continued detention of prisoners at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, in a move that seemed intended to symbolically separate the new administration from Bush detention policies.

articles.headline: Bad Economy Leads Patients to Put Off Surgery, or Rush It
articles.snippet: In a bad economy, patients are deferring elective surgeries or speeding them up in fear they might lose their insurance.
articles.abstract: In a bad economy, patients are deferring elective surgeries or speeding them up in fear they might lose their insurance.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the recession deepens, doctors and hospitals are reporting that hard-pressed patients are deferring elective surgery, like knee replacements and nose jobs, even as others are speeding up non-urgent procedures out of fear that they may soon lose their jobs and health insurance.

articles.headline: Weary of Looking for Work, Some Create Their Own
articles.snippet: Some laid-off workers are turning to their inner entrepreneur in what could be a boon for the economy.
articles.abstract: Some laid-off workers are turning to their inner entrepreneur in what could be a boon for the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Alex Andon, 24, a graduate of Duke University in biology, was laid off from a biotech company last May. For months he sought new work. Then, frustrated with the hunt, he turned to jellyfish.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Jenna Wortham

articles.headline: Foreclosing on a Plane, Then Flying It Away
articles.snippet: Ken Hill, who tracks down and repossesses aircraft for banks, is one of the busiest airplane repo men.
articles.abstract: Ken Hill, who tracks down and repossesses aircraft for banks, is one of the busiest airplane repo men.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ken Hill’s last business trip took him through eight states in January and netted him 12 planes. His current one is a 30- to 45-day trip for 27 more planes, his biggest ever.

articles.headline: Delaying College for a Year Could Have Benefits
articles.snippet: It is hard to see a downside to gaining a year of valuable life experience, especially since expanded federal college aid programs would not take effect until July 2010.
articles.abstract: It is hard to see a downside to gaining a year of valuable life experience, especially since expanded federal college aid programs would not take effect until July 2010.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, President Obama proposed what some experts called the most sweeping changes in federal college aid programs in decades. But even if Congress approves the new and expanded programs, they will not take effect until July 2010.

articles.headline: 3G Phones Exposing Networks’ Last-Gen Technology
articles.snippet: Industry analysts say the problems at mobile carriers are becoming more glaring as the growing popularity of so-called smartphones puts pressure on their networks.
articles.abstract: Industry analysts say the problems at mobile carriers are becoming more glaring as the growing popularity of so-called smartphones puts pressure on their networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Oh, the things modern mobile phones can do. They are music-playing, video-taking, direction-providing multimedia powerhouses. But many people have trouble getting them to perform their most basic functions, like making phone calls.

articles.headline: Intended to Incite, Irish Killings Draw Former Enemies Together
articles.snippet: The peaceful response to a killing in Northern Ireland seems to suggest the province is united against a return of violence.
articles.abstract: The peaceful response to a killing in Northern Ireland seems to suggest the province is united against a return of violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Irish Republican Army dissidents who shocked Northern Ireland this week by killing two British soldiers and a policeman within a 48-hour period have made no secret of their ambition to ignite a new wave of sectarian bloodletting.

articles.headline: Where Education and Assimilation Collide
articles.snippet: A record influx of immigrants has put classrooms on the front lines of America’s battles over whether and how to assimilate the newcomers and their children.
articles.abstract: A record influx of immigrants has put classrooms on the front lines of America’s battles over whether and how to assimilate the newcomers and their children.
articles.lead_paragraph: WOODBRIDGE, Va. — Walking the halls of Cecil D. Hylton High School outside Washington, it is hard to detect any trace of the divisions that once seemed fixtures in American society.

articles.headline: The Secrets of the Talent Scouts
articles.snippet: Executives in fields like entertainment and venture capital say it’s vital to keep recruiting even in a downturn.
articles.abstract: Executives in fields like entertainment and venture capital say it’s vital to keep recruiting even in a downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: AT most enterprises these days, hiring is in tatters. Bosses who once fretted over the talent wars are announcing hiring freezes, mass layoffs or pay cuts. Collapsing financial markets and a rapidly deteriorating economy have touched off a race to retrench.

articles.headline: At A.I.G., Good Luck Following the Money
articles.snippet: Nearly a third of the $170 billion in tax dollars given to American International Group went to other firms.
articles.abstract: Nearly a third of the $170 billion in tax dollars given to American International Group went to other firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: WE return this week to the subject of the American International Group, the giant insurer that has received $170 billion in taxpayer guarantees, because the clamor over its rescue continues to grow. Of concern to those on both Capitol Hill and Main Street is the secrecy surrounding the $50 billion funneled to A.I.G.’s counterparties since it nearly collapsed last fall.

articles.headline: Is It Time to Retrain B-Schools?
articles.snippet: Some are wondering if the way business students are taught may have contributed to the most serious economic crisis in decades.
articles.abstract: Some are wondering if the way business students are taught may have contributed to the most serious economic crisis in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHN Thain has one. So do Richard Fuld, Stanley O’Neal and Vikram Pandit. For that matter, so does John Paulson, the hedge fund kingpin.

articles.headline: Without a Pastor of His Own, Obama Turns to Five
articles.snippet: Since cutting his ties to the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., the president has cultivated new ones with other pastors.
articles.abstract: Since cutting his ties to the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., the president has cultivated new ones with other pastors.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama has been without a pastor or a home church ever since he cut his ties to the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr. in the heat of the presidential campaign. But he has quietly cultivated a handful of evangelical pastors for private prayer sessions on the telephone and for discussions on the role of religion in politics.

articles.headline: No Clear Accord on Stimulus by Top Industrial Nations
articles.snippet: Finance officials pledged “whatever action is necessary” but failed to offer specifics about a coordinated approach.
articles.abstract: Finance officials pledged “whatever action is necessary” but failed to offer specifics about a coordinated approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: HORSHAM, England  Two weeks before President Obama and the other leaders of the so-called Group of 20 nations meet to confront a global economic contraction, top finance officials meeting here Saturday committed to take “whatever action is necessary” to revive consumer demand and regulate global markets. Even so, they still seemed to have divergent views on what actions are required now.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Julia Werdigier

articles.headline: A.I.G. Planning Huge Bonuses After $170 Billion Bailout
articles.snippet: The insurer planned to pay about $165 million in bonuses by Sunday, though some payments were reduced after the Treasury secretary intervened.
articles.abstract: The insurer planned to pay about $165 million in bonuses by Sunday, though some payments were reduced after the Treasury secretary intervened.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The American International Group, which has received more than $170 billion in taxpayer bailout money from the Treasury and Federal Reserve, plans to pay about $165 million in bonuses by Sunday to executives in the same business unit that brought the company to the brink of collapse last year.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Administration Is Open to Taxing Health Benefits
articles.snippet: There are signs that the president is willing to reverse his opposition to the tax to help pay for health care changes.
articles.abstract: There are signs that the president is willing to reverse his opposition to the tax to help pay for health care changes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is signaling to Congress that the president could support taxing some employee health benefits, as several influential lawmakers and many economists favor, to help pay for overhauling the health care system.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Robert Pear

articles.headline: Pakistan Leader Backs Down and Reinstates Top Judge
articles.snippet: After a weekend of protests, the Pakistani government agreed to reinstate the former chief justice of the Supreme Court, a stunning concession to the opposition leader Nawaz Sharif.
articles.abstract: After a weekend of protests, the Pakistani government agreed to reinstate the former chief justice of the Supreme Court, a stunning concession to the opposition leader Nawaz Sharif.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — The Pakistani government agreed early on Monday to reinstate the independent-minded former chief justice of the Supreme Court, a stunning concession to the opposition leader Nawaz Sharif, who had been heading toward the capital in a convoy threatening to stage a mass protest over the issue after he broke free from house arrest at his residence near here.

articles.headline: Europe’s Hedging on Inmates Clouds Guantánamo Plans
articles.snippet: Some countries have begun raising questions about the risks and requirements if they accept prisoners.
articles.abstract: Some countries have begun raising questions about the risks and requirements if they accept prisoners.
articles.lead_paragraph: European countries that have offered to help the Obama administration close the detention center at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, have begun raising questions about the security risks and requirements if they accept prisoners described by the Bush administration as “the worst of the worst,” according to diplomats and other officials.
articles.byline: By William Glaberson and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: OPEC Opts for No Shift in Output
articles.snippet: Though the cartel would like to see oil prices at $60 to $70 a barrel, OPEC decided now was not the time to seek that increase.
articles.abstract: Though the cartel would like to see oil prices at $60 to $70 a barrel, OPEC decided now was not the time to seek that increase.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENNA  With energy consumption falling sharply as the global financial crisis worsens, the OPEC oil cartel said on Sunday that it would not seek to reduce its output, as fears about the world economy trumped calls to raise prices.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Capitalism Finds Voice in China TV
articles.snippet: Rui Chenggang’s nightly financial news program attracts 13 million viewers on China Central Television.
articles.abstract: Rui Chenggang’s nightly financial news program attracts 13 million viewers on China Central Television.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — At just 31 years old, Rui Chenggang has emerged as the media face of Chinese capitalism: young, smart and, to the dismay of some, deeply nationalistic.

articles.headline: Railroad Bailout May Offer a Model for Detroit
articles.snippet: When Northeastern railroads faltered in the 1970s, the federal government ran them until they recovered.
articles.abstract: When Northeastern railroads faltered in the 1970s, the federal government ran them until they recovered.
articles.lead_paragraph: As General Motors and Chrysler struggle to remain solvent, the railroad bailout of a generation ago could offer a template to the Obama administration  one in which the federal government would run the auto companies until they are back on their feet.

articles.headline: Computer Makers Prepare to Stake Bigger Claim in Phones
articles.snippet: Many PC makers and chip companies are charging into the mobile-phone business, promising new devices that can pack the horsepower of standard computers into palm-size packages.
articles.abstract: Many PC makers and chip companies are charging into the mobile-phone business, promising new devices that can pack the horsepower of standard computers into palm-size packages.
articles.lead_paragraph: The computer industry has hit upon its Next Big Thing. It is called a phone.

articles.headline: Next Big Film Has a Premiere in Your Living Room
articles.snippet: In an era where more and more films are vying for precious big screens, little movies are beginning to show up on small screens at the flick of the remote.
articles.abstract: In an era where more and more films are vying for precious big screens, little movies are beginning to show up on small screens at the flick of the remote.
articles.lead_paragraph: Austin, Tex.

articles.headline: Government Combs Through G.M.’s Survival Plan
articles.snippet: Officials traveled to Detroit in a last-minute effort to assess whether more government aid could make the company viable, or whether the better choice was a managed bankruptcy.
articles.abstract: Officials traveled to Detroit in a last-minute effort to assess whether more government aid could make the company viable, or whether the better choice was a managed bankruptcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Treasury officials and management experts hired by the Obama administration quietly began combing through General Motors’ latest downsizing plan in Detroit last week, in a last-minute effort to assess whether more government aid could make the company viable, or whether the better choice was a managed bankruptcy.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: A.I.G. Lists Banks It Paid With U.S. Bailout Funds
articles.snippet: Among the biggest recipients were Société Générale, Deutsche Bank and Goldman Sachs, all of which were owed money from credit default swaps.
articles.abstract: Among the biggest recipients were Société Générale, Deutsche Bank and Goldman Sachs, all of which were owed money from credit default swaps.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amid rising pressure from Congress and taxpayers, the American International Group on Sunday released the names of dozens of financial institutions that benefited from the Federal Reserve’s decision last fall to save the giant insurer from collapse with a huge rescue loan.

articles.headline: Bracing for a Backlash Over Wall Street Bailouts
articles.snippet: The Obama administration is worried that populist anger at financial institutions and Wall Street could complicate its agenda.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration is worried that populist anger at financial institutions and Wall Street could complicate its agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is increasingly concerned about a populist backlash against banks and Wall Street, worried that anger at financial institutions could also end up being directed at Congress and the White House and could complicate President Obama’s agenda.
